ENVIRONMENTAL IMPACT ASSESMENT: INTRODUCTION	
This Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) is carried out in accordance with the Iraqi Environmental Protection and Enhancement Law No. 27 for 2009. According to Articles 10 and 11 of the Law, any project that could result in negative environmental impacts shall be prohibited from carrying out its activities without the prior approval of the Ministry of Environment (MoEn), and the project owner should submit an EIA study prior to the commencement of any project activities. The provisions of the Law are applicable to existing establishments as well as their proposed expansions or upgrades (Article 12 of the Law).


Based on the nature of the project activities, its potential impacts and the surrounding sensitive environmental receptors, the EIA in hand was categorized according to the World Bank's definition as a Category B Environmental Assessment. This category refers to projects which have specific and localized environmental impacts and are not located in environmentally-sensitive areas.

The EIA team conducted desktop research and reviewed information that was made available for the project location within the city of Baghdad. The team also utilized satellite images to acquire further understanding of the project and its surrounding environmental and socio-economic situation.

The project activities, their impacts and specific mitigation measures are summarized in this report along with the necessary monitoring requirements. The report also indicates the roles and responsibilities for implementing the mitigation and monitoring measures. The environmental management and monitoring plan is intended to be practical and will need to be periodically reviewed and updated during the lifetime of the project. As such, it will serve as the cornerstone for ensuring the implementation of the EIA recommendations and any adjustments where and when deemed necessary in the future.


DESCRIPTION OF THE PROJECT AREA	
The proposed facility will be located in west bank of Tigris river in Baghdad.

The city had a remarkable urban development, but at the same time chaotic also as a consequence of the difficult war conditions, which allowed the phenomenon of illegal building. A phenomenon that, in fact, not taking into account the urban planning tools, has left an important scar on the territory not only from the point of view of the disorganization of the building but also of the insufficiency of the services offered.

In the recent remarkable reconstruction and order work that the Iraqi state is carrying out, an important part are the hygienic works and the purification service.

An important portion of the city's urban waste is absorbed by the Al-Kanshaa platform which currently reaches the Tigris river without purifying actions.

The new treatment plant will receive the sewage from the eastern portion of the big city with an important population density estimated at around 1,000,000 inhabitants. The new Al-Kanshaa plant will, due to its location and urban structure, become an integral part of the territory with the necessary attention to urban, environmental, historical and landscape data. The requirements will accommodate projected wastewater flows from both the present conveyance area limits and the future hypothetical improvements of the areas within the planning horizon for design that it is assumed to be 200,000 m3/day.



The objective of implementing the proposed facility is lift the sewage waters coming from sewage line North Eastern and to be treated and drained to Dyala river after treatment with the possibility of benefiting from treated waters for other reasons such irrigation, also, the possibility of using the waste resulting from treatment project to be used as organic compost in agricultural fields.

Considering the serious criticalities of the purification platform, and considering the ambitious goal of guaranteeing the quality of the waters of Dyala and Tigris rivers, STECI srl wants to face the design through the use of modern and effective analysis tools and software that take into consideration the parameters characteristic of the local reality in which the intervention is prefigured.


The service area for the wastewater collection system is presented in the next figure. The total surface of service area to build the WWTP, pointed out by hatch, is 126.607 m2 (48 dunums).




The WWTP will consist of three main areas each dedicated respectively to primary, biological and final treatments.






LEGISLATIVE FRAMEWORK	
The Iraqi Environmental Protection and Enhancement Law No. 27 for 2009 is the main legal document that outlines the environmental considerations for any project or activity to be carried out in the Country. However, there are other legislations that tackle specific environmental components.

This subsection will provide an overview of the legal requirements alongside the corresponding environmental component. Law No. 27 for 2009 will be presented in more details as it provides the requirements essential for obtaining environmental clearance for the project.



ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION AND ENHANCEMENT LAW NO. 27 FOR 2009 
As explained previously, Law No. 27 for 2009 states that projects that might result in negative environmental impacts shall conduct an EIA prior to their commencement. Article 10 within the Law states that the EIA report should include positive and negative impacts of the project on its surrounding and vice versa. In addition, the EIA should propose mitigation measures that shall ensure environmental compliance.

Furthermore, the Law also stipulates (through Article 9) that any establishment that will result in environmental pollution shall be committed to undertake the following measures:

Provide and implement pollution control measures using clean technologies, this is to be associated to ensuring the proper performance of these control measures
Provide tools for measuring the levels of pollutants. Records should be kept and made available to MoEn when needed. If such tools cannot be provided by the establishment, the MoEn performs these measurements
Build a database for environmental protection and sustainability
Reduce pollution through using renewable energy technologies



OTHER LEGISLATIONS	
This sub-section will present other legislations under the relevant environmental component.

WATER AND WASTEWATER

Regulation for the Protection of Water Resources No. 2 for 2001
Regulation for Protection of Rivers from Pollution No. 25 for 1967 and its amendment in 2001
Regulation for the Discharge of Wastewater No. 29 for 1934 and its amendments No. 35 for the same year




OCCUPATIONAL HEALTH AND SAFETY
Public Health Law No. 89 for 1981
Instructions No. 4 for 1989 (issued by virtue of the Public Health Law) for the Storage and Handling of Chemical Substances

ARCHAEOLOGY


The Law of Antiquities and Heritage No. 55 for 2002

INTERNATIONAL CONVENTIONS AND TREATIES


Iraq is part of a number of international conventions and treaties that aim to protect its environmental wealth. These include:

Convention on the Protection of World Cultural Heritage and Natural Heritage
Convention to Combat Desertification
Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (CITES)
Convention on Protection of Migratory Species of Wild Animals
RAMSAR Convention on the Protection of Wetlands and Wetland Values


ENVIRONMENTAL BASELINE	

CLIMATE	
Baghdad has geographical coordinates 333°N and 44.4°E. Winds reaching the city are generally dry and because of the aridity and the relatively cloudless skies, there are large variations in daily temperature as well as between seasons and regions.

Climate and meteorology are studied in order to have environmental parameters as guide for WWTP treatments.

The climate of Baghdad is arid, subtropical, and continental. The mean maximum temperature in July and August is about 43°C, which could reach up to 49°C in hot seasons. Dust storms are common in summer and the winter is chilly. The mean annual rainfall ranges from about 120 mm in the south to about 160 mm in the northeast. Prevailing wind direction is Northwestern. And an exceptional flood is expected every 30 years.

TEMPERATURE


Bilal, Al-Jumaily, A.Habbib, 2013 in their published study examined the trends of the monthly, seasonal and annual Tmin, Tmax, and Tmean time series for Baghdad, for the period 1941–2000. The most important aspects of their results are the significant increase in Tmax and Tmean during the spring season and a significant decrease in all three temperatures during the autumn season.

From: Dheyaa A. Bilal, Kais J. Al-Jumaily, Enas A.Habbib - Air temperature trends in Baghdad, Iraq for the period 1941-2000












From: Dheyaa A. Bilal, Kais J. Al-Jumaily, Enas A.Habbib - Air temperature trends in Baghdad, Iraq for the period 1941-2000



To complete the temperature analysis Muter, Kadhum, Hassan published a study in which they characterized the summer season. In their study, dthey escribe monthly air temperatures for Baghdad’s hot season using statistical method for maximum temperatures and understand the behavior of begin early summer and check changes in the length and the strength of Baghdad’s hot season between 1970 and 2017, especially the changes that change in May. Thirty years of data is long enough to calculate an average that is not influenced by year-to- year variability.

Figures above are taken from Muter, Kadhum, Hassan Approaching of May maximum surface air temperature to characteristic summer season for Baghdad city study.















The effect of Baghdad location, climate change, increased air temperature, and variation of surface air temperature lead to increased maximum air temperature for all season particularly in spring make may approaching to summer season. The behavior of air temperature for Baghdad city during the summer months tends to increase despite the fluctuations between the increase and decrease. Such observations are consistent with global trends in temperature.

Analyzing temperature data from hydrologic years is possible to calculate maximum, minimum and mean temperature values.

HUMIDITY


Atmospheric humidity is a term that describes the amount of water vapor in the air, and the distinction between dry and wet air in the atmosphere is through the presence of water vapor or not. Water vapor is the invasive state of moisture in the atmosphere it is the most present condition in the atmosphere, where water is also present in a liquid form, such as cloud droplets or raindrops in a solid state such as snow and hail. The amount of moisture in the air varies with humidity, depending on the temperature and air pressure, as the air humidity is directly proportional to the temperature and inversely with air pressure. The warmer air, the more water vapor it carries because the high air pressure lowers the evaporation process by preventing the evaporated particles from escaping from the water surface to the atmosphere, and when the air contains the maximum amount of water vapor that can carry it under a certain temperature and pressure, then it is said that the air has been saturated with water vapor.

Water vapor pressure: It is the partial pressure of water vapor as a gas component of the atmosphere.
Absolute humidity: The amount of weight of water vapor present in the air at a specific temperature.
Specific humidity: It is the ratio of the mass of water vapor to the mass of moist air that is associated with it.
Dew point: It is the temperature at which water vapor begins to condense
Mixing ratio: Is the ratio between the mass of water vapor to the mass of dry air with which water vapor is associated



Relative humidity: The ratio of the real vapor pressure to the saturated vapor pressure at air temperature.

Relative humidity is the most common way of expressing air humidity, as it is a measure of the degree to which the air approaches the saturation of water vapor. If the air contains half of the amount of water vapor that it can carry only, then this humidity equals 50%, and the air is saturated with moisture that associated with shrouding in clouds and fog then the relative humidity in this case is 100%. In addition, the lower air layers over the oceans are saturated with humidity that reaches 100%. In the Sahara Desert and the subtropical desert regions, the relative humidity drops to only 10%. There are several ways to measure them, including: 1- Hygrometer with dry and wet probes. 2- The capillary hygrometer.

The high temperature with high humidity increases the transform of heat from the air to the body and at the same time impedes evaporation, which makes the body does not cool quickly and its temperature becomes annoying. But during cold weather, high humidity increases the transfer of heat from the body to the surrounding atmosphere, which causes the body to lose a portion of its heat at the time when it needs such heat. Long periods of heat or long periods of cold have a significant impact on the vital signs of a person. Hence, we conclude that high temperature and extreme cold are harmful to human health because the human body will maintain its internal temperature, which is 37 ºC. Whereas, high and low humidity are also harmful to human health. The humid atmosphere helps the growth of bacteria, germs, and causes laziness and lethargy, but the moderate-humid air is comfortable and healthy and is better than wet or dry air. The relative humidity of a region differs greatly during the day, even though the amount of water vapor in the air remains the same, and in such cases the relative humidity changes when the temperature increases or decreases, the relative humidity may be higher in the morning, when the temperature is low and the air is unable to carry more water vapor than it did at that time, but when the temperature increases during the day, the air becomes able to carry more water vapor, thus reducing the amount of relative humidity. As the air cools under a specified pressure and a constant amount of water vapor, it reaches a temperature with which it becomes saturated. This temperature called the dew point, but if the temperature is lower than that, the water vapor begins to condense and clouds, fog, or Dew. Thus, the lower the air temperatures relative to the amount of dew in it, the higher the relative humidity.

Atmospheric humidity in the atmosphere increases directly with increasing temperature, that is, the higher the temperature, the higher the air humidity. For this reason, the humidity in the tropical regions increases, while in the Polar Regions decreases. It also increases in marine areas compared to land areas. The same can be said when comparing low areas (high humidity) and high areas (low humidity). The temperature is also affected by the humidity. Water vapor is a gas that absorbs thermal energy. The temperature of the gaseous envelope saturated with water vapor decreases by 1 km / 5 ° C, while decreases by 1 km / 10 ° C in case of non-saturated water vapor. In addition, the humidity decreases as the height increases because 90% of the water in the atmosphere is concentrated in the first five kilometers. This phenomenon is explained by moving away from water sources. The weight of water plays a fundamental role in the presence of this substance near the surface of the globe.

Weather and Climate in Iraq has a hot climate in most of spring, summer, and autumn months. Average temperatures in Iraq range from above 39 ° C in July and August to below zero in January. Figure below shows the annual average temperature in Iraq. Most of the rains occur from November and December until the end of



April, and the most abundant ones are in the mountainous region in northern Iraq. The summer months are accompanied by dry Southern and Southeastern winds, as well as dusty winds that occur from April to June and second from late September to November and Northern and Northwestern winds prevail from mid-June to mid- September, where dust storms accompany these winds. The climate in the Western and Southern desert regions is characterized by hot Summers and cold Winters. This region also experiences short violent rainstorms in Winter. As for the Southeastern region, most of its rain is accompanied by thunderstorms in Winter and early Spring. The average annual average rainfall for this region is around 10-17 cm, and half of the Winter days are cloudy, and in Summer the weather is clear except for periods of dust storms in Norther part of Iraq. The Kurdistan region, there is mountains that extend in the North and Northeast of Iraq, and the region's climate is characterized by mild Summers and cold Winters, and rain occurs mainly here in Winter and Spring, and is also accompanied by falling amounts of snow in many places.


WIND


Atmospheric temperature changes due to the effects of solar radiation cause differences in atmospheric pressure. Therefore, the wind will be created according to the movement of air. The wind is generated by pressure differences so that air moves from places of high pressure to others with low pressure. Each of the direction, speed, and gustiness are features of the wind. The wind is not seen, so we see things being moved by it. Then the movement of objects as air passes them is an indication of wind direction. Anemometers are used



to measure wind speed. Beaufort scale can be used by ordinary people to indicate the speed of the wind from its influence on surroundings. The Coriolis force increases when the wind speed increase. The stronger the wind, the greater the deflection. Coriolis force is one of the important factors that affect wind speed. The direction of the wind is an important factor in the siting of a wind energy conversion system. It is reported by the direction from which it originates. The power that can be extracted from the wind is one of the reliable sources to minimize the dependence on fossil fuel-generated electricity. Wind power can be generated by using wind turbines. In Iraq, Wind energy can be classified into three zones, 48% of Iraq has low annual wind speed, 35% has annual wind speed 3.1e4.9 m/s, 8% has relatively high annual wind speed, and the residual has calm values. The diurnal pattern of wind speed in Iraq has peak values at mid-day and early hours of the morning, the peak values of wind speed varies in the range 5e10 m/s. The use of wind as a source of energy is becoming popular because it is clean and renewable. There is a pressing need in Iraq to develop site-based technology on wind energy, which can be used for the optimal design of wind farms. Therefore, many papers and researches have been carried out to analyze the statistical wind speed data obtained from measurements along a period of 25 years at 9 sites in Iraq, to indicate the superior sites among the selected sites with respect to the wind speed as well as knowing the best periods of wind speed during the year. A lot of research has been done around the world in the field of data mining for site assessment. Data mining using ARIMA or any other technique has been employed to analyzing wind speed data, wind speed prediction, and wind speed modeling for a wind farm and cost estimation. The time series for wind speed were used for different parts from Iraq in this work to draw map covering all region of Iraq which is located in the south-west of Asia between (29e37 N) and (39e48 E).

The monthly wind speed average data were obtained from Iraqi meteorological organization and seismology (IMOS) for (9) Stations. These data were analyzed using an arc map program, which is one of the Geographic Information System programs. Arc map was used to analyze the monthly mean wind speed for several stations (Mosul, Kirkuk, Khanqin, Baghdad, Hai, Dewaniya, Amara, Nasiriya, and Basrah), which are located at the north, middle and south of Iraq respectively for the period from (1985e2010). This period was divided into five parts from 1985 into 2010. The steps of each part are five years. Every year in this period (1985,1990, 1995, 2000, 2005, 2010) was divided into four months (Dec., Mar., Jul., Oct.), which correlate to the four seasons. The Tables 1e4 containing data averages of wind speed for the nine stations, which show the spatial distribution for data sorted by seasons showing the temporal distribution.








RAINFALL


The present chapter aims to analyze the trend and forecast annual rainfall in Baghdad for the period of 1979- 2019. Abd Al-Ghani and Mohammed Ali (2020) study Trend of Rain in Iraq show that rainy season tends to decrease in almost stations but Baghdad station tended to rise, as the rate of change in it reached (21.6+, 10.9
+) mm during the fall and spring seasons respectively.

Data have been acquired a mainly monthly average of rainfall data from the Iraqi Meteorological Organization and seismology (IMOS). The long-term data of the monthly average rainfall for the time period 1979-2019 were collected from the Baghdad station. Monthly rainfall for 39 years for Baghdad city is available which covers 24 years are continuous data from 1979 to 2002, two years missing (2003-2004) and 15 years to 2019 are continuous. The daily rainfall behavior varies widely from the extreme values 89 mm in Baghdad to the minimum
mm in addition to the persisting of rain for one day and up to more than four days but most of the non-rainy



days in the year (Abd, Abdulkareem, 2020). The behavior of annual rainfall in Baghdad varies greatly as shown in next figure.



Annual rainfall series for Baghdad city (1979-2019)
From: Khtan, Al-Atabi - Analyzing and prediction of rainfall trends over Baghdad city


Analyzing precipitation data from hydrologic years is possible to calculate maximum, minimum and mean annual precipitation values:

Maximum:	296.7 mm
Minimum:	57.6 mm
Mean:	125.3 mm
Monthly, seasonal, and annual data of precipitation for the study period were used to calculate percentile-based indices. Precipitation data were represented by the 25th percentile to describe extreme dry conditions and the 90th for extreme wet conditions. Results show that precipitation amounts between 10 and 20 mm had the greatest frequency; daily precipitation amounts between 90 and 100 mm occurred only once at Baghdad station (Naqi, Al-Jiboori, Al-Madhhachi, 2021). The 90th percentile was 17 mm while the total accumulated precipitation during the period was 2380.2 mm.





WATER  RESOURCES	
There are surface water bodies within the project area. The groundwater bodies within the project area were found to have a shallow water table. Thus, water which has percolated into the soil reaches groundwater at a higher rate.

DIYALA RIVER


Diyala River is a tributary of Tigris River, it is one of the important rivers in Iraq. The Diyala River originates near Sanandaj in the Zagros Mountains in Iran, forming the Iran-Iraq border for over 30 km. With a total length of 574 km, 17 the river has a drainage area of 33,240 km2, of which 25% are located in Iran and 75% in Iraq (see next Overview Map). The Diyala joins the Tigris 15 km south of Baghdad (see next Overview Map). Its principal tributaries are the Tanjeru, Sirwan and Wand Rivers.

The Diyala stream-flow is very similar to that of the Lesser Zab. It is characterized by peak flows in April and a low-flow season from July until November.

Diyala river, downstream tributary to the south of Baghdad of Tigris river, has a mean daily flow of 182 m3/s at the confluence with Tigris.

From: UN-ESCWA and BGR (United Nations Economic and Social Commission for Western Asia; Bundesanstalt für Geowissenschaften und Rohstoffe). 2013. Inventory of Shared Water Resources in Western Asia. Beirut.




GROUNDWATER

In general, groundwater is widely used for irrigation, industrial activities, drinking, and domestic purposes. Rapid growth of population, urbanization, industrialization, and agriculture activities increase its exploitation, reduce availability, and enhance vulnerability to contaminate the quality of water.

An attempt has been made to assess the overall groundwater quality and identify major variables affecting the groundwater quality in the urban area of Baghdad. Groundwater samples from tube wells were analyzed for the major physicochemical variables by Alhassan H. Ismail, Muntasir A.H. and Reem J. Channo who published their results in Groundwater Quality Assessment in Urban Area of Baghdad, Iraq, Using Multivariate Statistical Techniques, Eng. &Tech.Journal, Vol.33,Part (A),No.2, 2015.

The Authors, from the Hill–Piper trilinear diagram observed that the majority of ground water from sampling sites are Ca2+ -Mg2+ -Cl- -SO 42- type and Na2+ -K+ -Cl- -SO 42- type water. Hill (1940) has developed a pattern diagram and later improved by Piper (1944, 1953) to form of trilinear diagram, which is an effective tool in segregating analysis data with respect to sources of the dissolved constituents in groundwater.

Multivariate statistical techniques such as factor analysis and cluster analysis were applied to identify the major factors (variables) corresponding to the different source of variation in groundwater quality of Baghdad. Factor analysis identified three major factors explaining 82.506% of the total variance in water quality; and the major variations are related to degree of mineralization of the geological components of soils, irrigation return flow, agricultural activities and mixing of wastewater. Hierarchical cluster analysis revealed three different groups of similarities between the sampling sites, reflecting different physicochemical properties and pollution levels in the groundwater quality.

From: Groundwater Quality Assessment in Urban Area of Baghdad, Iraq, Using Multivariate Statistical Techniques, Eng. &Tech.Journal, Vol.33,Part (A),No.2, 2015.




From: Groundwater Quality Assessment in Urban Area of Baghdad, Iraq, Using Multivariate Statistical Techniques, Eng. &Tech.Journal, Vol.33,Part (A),No.2, 2015.


Three latent factors were identified as responsible for the data structure, explaining 82.506% of total variance in the data set. The first factor explained 59.627% of the total variance and mainly related to mineralization and irrigation return flow. The second factor explained 11.569% which represents the agricultural activities from agricultural areas such as fertilization and mixing of wastewater whereas, the third factor explained 11.309% of the variances and reflects the acidity–alkalinity scale in groundwater.



From: Groundwater Quality Assessment in Urban Area of Baghdad, Iraq, Using Multivariate Statistical Techniques, Eng. &Tech.Journal, Vol.33,Part (A),No.2, 2015.


SOIL	
In 1965, the Iraq government formed the State Board for Land Reclamation, which was charged with mapping the soils or Iraq. To date this governmental entity drafted an exploratory map of the entire country.

The soil classification revealed the following soil types in Iraq: Aridisol (~45%), Entisol (~20%), Inceptisol (~15%), Vertisol (~10%), Alfisol (~5%), and Mollisol (~5%). Soils formed near the Euphrates and Tigris Rivers are dominated by relatively fertile alluvial soils within the Entisol soil order, while those in the south and western deserts are barren and marginal rangeland soils within the Aridisol soil order. Soils in the northern Zagros Mountain Range receive up to ten times the annual precipitation as those of the southwestern regions, and as a result, soils of the Mollisol, Alfisol, and Vertisol soil order can be found in the northern foothills up to the Iraqi- Iranian border.


Exploratory map of the soils of Iraq



The Quaternary period (including Pleistocene and Holocene ages) affected the formation and nature of soil in Iraq. During this period, many processes took place that caused some erosion in the mountains and hills. Terraces have been formed along the Tigris and Euphrates Rivers and their tributaries as a result of changing climate. Rivers and wind filled up the Mesopotamian plain with fine texture sediments. Moreover, secondary gypsum crest has been formed and covered large areas of the deserts and the Mesopotamian plain. Almost all the soil of center and southern parts of Iraq became saline due to the natural conditions and the shallow level of ground water. Due to repeated flooding and irrigation practices, layers of mud accumulated on the original soil. As a result, most of the basin areas of the rivers are of silty soil. Quaternary sediments are covering nearly 30% of the Iraqi surface area as it can be noticed on the geological map (Figure below). They are important for the human activities and engineering works


Geological map of Iraq
From.: Sissakian, V.K. (2000) Geological Map of Iraq. 3rd Edition, State Company of Geological Survey and Mining, Baghdad.


Baghdad is located in the central part of the country in the middle Mesopotamian plain (Figure above). The area is covered by accumulation of the deposits brought by the two rivers (Tigris and Euphrates). The area was occupied by humans since the dawn of civilization. Early human activities affected the soil formations because they were depending mainly on agriculture, irrigation and farm practices. These activities made numerous changes in the soil characteristics from one place to another. Over the years, soil became a sequential stratum from alluvial and sand sediment. The changing course of the river caused changes in the flood plain of the river



and thus changing the sequences of the deposited layers. These changes gave the soil at Baghdad unexpected and misleading characteristics. Moreover, the soil is saline because of the arid climate. Based on the nature of Baghdad, soils are mostly of fluvial origin (clayey and silty) with some gypsiferous soil, and sand.

Gypseous soils are one of the most complex materials that challange the geotechnical engineers. In Iraq it has been reported that several structures have experienced different patterns of cracks and uneven deformations generated primearly from the exposion of the supporting gypseous soils to water. It is a well known fact that gypseous soils demonstrate high bearing capacity and very low compressibility when they are in the dry state. On the contrary a sudden collapsibile behaviour was reported when the gypseous soils are exposed to water.The collapsibility of gypseous soils results from the direct contact of water. The dissolution of different types of salts contained inside the mass of gypseous soil will generate new pores inside the soil skeleton and loosen the cementing bonds between the particles. This process creates a meta stable structure that facilitates the sliding of particles into a more dense state. The rate of dissolution of gypsum depends primarily on environmental changes in moisture content generating from fluctuation of ground water table and /or surface water, climate changes typically temperature, permeability and state of flow conditions in addition to the type and content of gypsum. (Ref. Challenging Problems of Gypseous Soils in Iraq, Al-Saoudi N.K.S., Al-Khafaji A.N., Al-Mosawi M.J., 2013). (FAO 1990), although more recent study (Ismail 1994) reported that gypseous soils cover 31.7 % of the total area of Iraq. The first map demonstrating the distribution of gypsum in Iraq was presented by (Buringh 1960) indicating five zones as shown in next figure.


First map of distribution of gypsum in Iraq
From.: Al- Saoudi N.K.S., Al- Khafaji A.N., Al- Mosawi M.J. (2013), , V.K. (2000) Challenging Problems of Gypseous Soils in Iraq.



The primary gypsum is located in the extreme north area between tigres and euphraties rivers. The second zone where primary gypsum mixed with limstone located below and parrallel to the euphraties river extending from the west desert to the south. The secondary gypsum is identified in two areas, one in the north below the first zone and one in the south – west. The fourth zone is gypsiferous alluvium extens from the north in a narrow band and gradually widened towards the south. The fifth zone representing the non gypsiferous soil, mainly limestone is identified in two ares one in the north east and the other in the west desert.

A more refined map exhibiting the distribution of gypsum in Iraq was presented by Al-Barrazanji (Gypsiferous soils in Iraq., 1973). He investigated thoroughyl the type and gypsum content in different parts of Iraq and proposed the map shown in next figure. Six zones are distiguished according to their origin and gypsum content.


Distribution of gypsum in Iraq (Al Barazanji 1973)
From.: Al- Saoudi N.K.S., Al- Khafaji A.N., Al- Mosawi M.J. (2013), , V.K. (2000) Challenging Problems of Gypseous Soils in Iraq.



Characterization of land use/ land cover over large areas is an essential task in any environmental design because it provides a baseline for designers to seek sustainable livelihoods in harmony with ecosystems.

Deriving land cover information from satellite data is one of the most common applications employed to monitor, evaluate, and manage the environment.

In the next figure is presented the result of a study, that classified Landsat-8 satellite images with spatial resolution of 30m, obtained from U.S. Geological Survey (USGS) according the Maximum Likelihood Classifier method that is considered among the most established algorithms for land cover change detection studies.

Applying classification method the land cover was classified into four classes, namely:

vegetation
water
urban area
barren soil
For the year 2020, the percentages were as follows: Urban area represents 42.8%, vegetation represents 36.2%, water represents 3%, and barren soil represents 18%.

-Classification of land cover /land use for Baghdad city at 2020
From: L.K. Abbas - Mapping Land Cover/Land Use for Change Derivation Using Remote Sensing and GIS Technique



Land use / Land cover data will become an analytic tool that allows to ask questions about the relationship between these features and, as they refer to real-world coordinate systems, to other masterplan maps, representing conditions on the ground.

All the data will be georeferenced by means of QGIS, an open source, Geographic Information System (GIS) software to do analysis.

Baghdad is part of a geological formation called the Mesopotamian Plain Region so its sediments are recent not exceeding Quaternary ages. The land is considered highly flat with no clear natural drainage pattern. Baghdad has a Calcaric Fluvisols soil type with about 20% of lime. Most soils of Baghdad area are therefore secondary soils (residual soils) derived from the above regions, transported from place of weathering and accumulated as a result of sedimentation. Besides, Baghdad soil strata are affected by river course changes during previous decades leading to coarse silt deposits and giving different depositional stratigraphy each few meters, thus Baghdad strata are erratic, somewhat are nonhomogeneous with a water table near ground. This soil in generally is alkaline with poor permeability (NCCL, 1986; Karim and Schanz, 2006). Organic matter content is low and the carbon nitrogen ration is narrow.

The main stratigraphic units of Baghdad soil are: landfill layer consists of cohesive and non-cohesive materials; the upper natural sub-soil strata consists mainly clay or brown silty clay or clayey silt sometimes with sand or a little amount of gravel; while the lower layer is the natural soil strata consists of medium dense to very dense brown to grey sand mixed with gravel or lenses of clay or silty clay (NCCL, 1986; Karim and Schanz, 2006). The depositional conditions of Baghdad area during geological times, such as and human activities, affect the nature of Baghdad soil and its groundwater quality. Baghdad soil is characterized by its high salinity due to dryness, rainfall scarcity and evaporation leading to groundwater upward movement and causing fluctuation of groundwater levels in the area.

From: M. Al-Saffar - Baghdad; City of Cultural Heritage and Monumental Islamic Architecture


From: Baghdad Comprehensive City Development Plan 2030 http://www.unit44.net/practice/ecological-planning/project-57bb6afbd6acd0-59570009


BIODIVERSITY	
There are four vegetation zones in Iraq: the desert, the steppe, the mountain forest, and the Alpine regions. The formation of the short-lived herbaceous plants in the mountain forest and the alpine regions is due to the low rainfall rates. Desert and steppe regions lacks any arboreal types. The northern region of Iraq is mountainous with relatively high rainfall rates, thus it sustains virgin forests, man-made forests, and a large number of crop plants and their wild relatives. Zagros Mountains suffer from over cutting and overgrazing, which consequently caused a reduction in some of Iraq’s oak forests to scrublands. Higher elevations include alpine plants that can survive harsh weather. It is evident that biodiversity in Iraq is under increasing threat of ecosystem destruction due to overgrazing and mismanagement of rangelands. The major ecological concern in the northern highlands and mountains is deforestation. The northern regions in Iraq are supports a wide range of stone fruit trees, both wild and domesticated. Central and southern Iraq is known for the evergreen fruit trees, including date palm. Figure below demonstrates the distribution of Key Biodiversity Areas (KBAs) in Iraq.




Key Biodiversity Areas (KBAs) of Iraq


IMPACTS ASSESMENT AND PROPOSED MITIGATION MEASURES	

ODOR	
During WWTP operation, generation of some level of hydrogen sulfide gas (H2S) will create odors especially at the initial pumping station, the screening, the sand removal, the primary sedimentation, the thickener and the areas of the plant in which sludge handling allows its contact with the atmosphere.

However, the design should optimize the configuration so as to minimize the conditions that cover generation of bad odors. As a mitigation measure, the proposed design adopted bio filtration technology to minimize odors generation.

REUSE ISSUES	
The quality of the treated effluent will be suitable for irrigation. However, there are number of issues that should be considered. First, the effluent should be tested at discharge point to ensure E.coli limits of 100 MPN of total E.coli form in 100 ml of water. In addition, irrigation methods should comply with WHO instruction whereby sprinkler irrigation is not permitted. Moreover, crop types and harvesting periods should be determined to avoid public health hazards. On the other hand, public perception of reuse should also be taken into consideration. Public opposition to effluent reuse in irrigation can be mitigated by public awareness on the risks and benefits of reclaimed water reuse.

As regarding the disposal of the final stabilized sludge that comes out from the WWTP, it is intended to be safely discharged in authorized landfills and there is no potential for reutilization.

VECTOR BREEDING	
Anaerobic tanks can attract aquatic insects such as mosquitoes, which are known vectors of malaria and encephalitis. However, the decreased number of cesspits and elimination of wastewater flowing in open channels will decrease the vector breeding habitats within the served areas.

If necessary, insecticide should be used to control vector breeding in the area surrounding the treatment plant.

SLUDGE  HANDLING	
The produced sludge will be stabilized to avoid odor generation. In addition, sludge will be adequately dehydrated to facilitate transportation to the disposal landfill.

However, proper handling of sludge should be emphasised. Such practices may include marking the transporting vehicles with a clear font. In addition to preventing any leakage of liquids from vehicles or dispersion of sludge from the surface by covering the whole load so that no treated sludge can find its way out of the vehicle.


PROTECTION OF WATER RESOURCES	
The proposed project will reduce the possibility of groundwater contamination due to percolation from individual tanks. However, the groundwater contamination from wastewater in treatment tanks can be avoided by lining of the tanks.

On the other hand, discharge of the treated effluent to a river is not expected to pose public health hazard. This is because the effluent will be disinfected before discharge.

INDUSTRIAL DISCHARGE	
According to the wastewater analysis, the influent is mainly due to domestic wastewater and there are no records of toxic/inhibitors compounds that come from industrial discharge. However, for future purpose, the potential discharge of industrial wastewater in the Al-Khansaa WWTP upstream shall be continuously monitored and prevented. The most threatening impact coming from industrial discharge is that it is full of inhibitor compounds that may affect the pH of the water and the biological activity, this can ultimately cause the failure of the biological treatment processes. High concentrations of these toxic and inhibitor compounds, such as heavy metals, pharmaceuticals, fertilizers and chemical compounds, are of great concern because of their persistence and non-degradability. Therefore, it is recommended, as a mitigation measure, to monitor that in the future Industrial plants will not discharge upstream of the Al-Khansaa WWTP. In the case that this scenario cannot be avoided, it should be mandatory that every industrial plant has to be provided of its own localized wastewater treatment unit.

EMPLOYMENT AND DEVELOPMENT	
During construction, the local economy and working population are expected to benefit from the proposed project which will generate direct and indirect temporary employment opportunities. During operation of the WWTP a number of permanent job opportunities will be available for technical positions as well as for labours. However, to increase the effect of this positive impact, priority in hiring should be given to qualified locals.

OCCUPATIONAL SAFETY AND HEALTH	
During operation of the new facility, workers involved in the daily functions of the plant will be exposed to hazards such as contact with the wastewater during maintenance works.

Protective gear such as masks, gloves, long boots and protective suits should be provided to workers when undertaking repair activities or any activity that poses biohazards. Separate protective gears should be assigned to each worker and sharing should be limited to avoid transmission of diseases. The gears should be inspected for contamination or loss of integrity (holes, cracks, etc.) prior to use. Workers should be trained on safe removal techniques for contaminated protective gears and other clothing.



In addition, safety training for all staff members should be required to minimize injuries within the facility. Workers should be familiar with the location of the first aid station or kit, each fire alarm and each fire extinguisher.

Project Overview 
The project involves the development of a waste treatment plant with a capacity of 150,000 m3/day, strategically located to address the wastewater management needs of Medical City in Baghdad. It is committed to environmental sustainability and legal compliance.
Environmental, Social & Financial Impact
Untreated wastewater can have serious effects on the environment to the extent high levels of Contaminated water cannot be reused, If the wastewater is dumped into lakes or rivers means we are using up dwindling supplies of natural water resources.
This process of dumping wastewater into the natural water supply can pose hazards not only to human health, but can also have a devastating effect on wildlife, especially for fish and other small creatures which live in water. Harmful substances in water can also get into fields and soil, which results in smaller crop yields for farmers. 
The damage to ecosystems due to excessive wastewater discharges has impacts beyond the environment. Economic impacts, such as pumping waste water into Dijlah river, will cause losses to the population since river banks normally are invested for tourism, commercial and employment opportunities. 
In the economic analysis of this investment, the ecological externalities of the project were monetized, starting from the assumption that the wastewater treatment process is a process that has desired output—treated water—but also undesirable outputs, such as suspended particles, etc. Their estimated value, determined by “shadow prices”, actually represents the avoided damage/costs, i.e., the realized benefit/income for the environment as a result of the removal of pollutants during treatment in the WWTP. 
The difference between the pollution costs for wastewater and the pollution costs for treated water represents the realized savings in the cost of pollution, i.e., environmental benefits. For example, the suspended particles. The final results of the conducted economic cost-benefit analysis unequivocally indicate the full socio-economic justification for the investment. At the same time, the sensitivity analysis proved that the project is resistant to possible changes in input parameters over time.

Iraq’s environmental legislation and policy have been influenced by several factors, such as population growth, war, climate change, poor land use planning, and encroachment on fragile ecosystems1. Iraq faces serious environmental problems, such as poor water quality, soil salinity, air pollution, conflict pollution, deterioration of key ecosystems, climate change impacts, and threat of water shortages2.

Iraq has enacted some laws and regulations to protect and improve its environment, such as Law No. 27 of 2009 for Protection and Improvement of Environment3, the law of Ministry of Environment 2008, and the order (4) of 20124. These laws aim to prevent, control, or reduce environmental pollution, preserve public health, natural resources, biodiversity, and cultural heritage, and ensure sustainable development3.

Iraq is also a signatory to several international environmental agreements, such as the Paris Agreement on climate change, the Convention on Biological Diversity, the Basel Convention on hazardous waste, and the Stockholm Convention on persistent organic pollutants5. Iraq has submitted its national reports and action plans to these conventions, and has received technical and financial support from international organizations, such as the UN Environment Programme (UNEP) and the UN Development Programme (UNDP), to implement its environmental commitments15.

However, Iraq still faces many challenges and gaps in its environmental governance, such as lack of reliable data, weak enforcement and monitoring, insufficient public awareness and participation, inadequate institutional capacity and coordination, and limited financial resources25. Iraq needs to strengthen its environmental legal framework, improve its compliance with international standards, enhance its cooperation with regional and global partners, and integrate environmental considerations into its post-conflict recovery and development plans15.

For augmenting the Environmental Baseline Section with specific environmental data, the study "Evaluating the Effects of Medical City Wastewater on Water Quality of Tigris River" is particularly relevant. The research collected water samples monthly from four locations along the Tigris River within Baghdad to analyze various physiochemical parameters such as temperature, pH, electrical conductivity, turbidity, dissolved oxygen (DO), chemical oxygen demand (COD), biological oxygen demand (BOD), total hardness, chlorides, and nitrates.

Key findings from the study include:
- Elevated mean values for electrical conductivity, turbidity, COD, chlorides, total hardness, and nitrates at the discharge point of Medical City, significantly higher than those at other sites.
- Water tends to be alkaline with pH values ranging from 7.0 to 8.8.
- DO mean values varied significantly, indicating potential impacts on aquatic life.
- BOD and COD mean values were also recorded, with COD values ranging notably high, suggesting substantial organic pollution.

The results indicated that many of these parameters exceeded the permissible limits set by Iraqi and WHO standards for protecting surface water, pointing to heavy pollution mainly from untreated sewage and other industrial and agricultural activities.

Abstract
The Environmental Impact Report for the Medical City & Al Zuyut Vertical Waste Treatment Plant project in Baghdad presents an in-depth analysis of Iraq's critical water management challenges and proposes a sustainable solution. This report synthesizes data from various studies, including the impact of untreated wastewater on the Tigris River and regional health, and introduces an advanced treatment shaft technology designed to significantly enhance water quality. It evaluates the environmental implications of the current scenario, the efficacy of the proposed technology, and its compliance with Iraqi environmental laws, including law Law No 27 of 2009 for Protection and Improvement of Environment.. The report underscores the necessity of this project in mitigating water pollution, safeguarding public health, and contributing to Iraq's sustainable development.
Introduction
Iraq's struggle with water management, particularly in urban areas like Baghdad's Medical City, necessitates an innovative approach to wastewater treatment. The Medical City & Al Zuyut Vertical Waste Treatment Plant project, with a capacity of 150,000 m3/day, is conceived to address these challenges. This report outlines the project’s objectives, detailing the deployment of cutting-edge treatment shaft technology to improve water quality and meet environmental sustainability goals. Emphasizing legal compliance and socio-economic benefits, the report provides an introduction to the current environmental standards, the legislative framework the project will adhere to, the treatment methodology and its expected impact.
Environmental, Social & Financial Impact
Untreated wastewater can have serious effects on the environment to the extent high levels of Contaminated water cannot be reused, If the wastewater is dumped into lakes or rivers means we are using up dwindling supplies of natural water resources.
This process of dumping wastewater into the natural water supply can pose hazards not only to human health, but can also have a devastating effect on wildlife, especially for fish and other small creatures which live in water. Harmful substances in water can also get into fields and soil, which results in smaller crop yields for farmers. 
The damage to ecosystems due to excessive wastewater discharges has impacts beyond the environment. Economic impacts, such as pumping waste water into Dijlah river, will cause losses to the population since river banks normally are invested for tourism, commercial and employment opportunities. 
In the economic analysis of this investment, the ecological externalities of the project were monetized, starting from the assumption that the wastewater treatment process is a process that has desired output—treated water—but also undesirable outputs, such as suspended particles, etc. Their estimated value, determined by “shadow prices”, actually represents the avoided damage/costs, i.e., the realized benefit/income for the environment as a result of the removal of pollutants during treatment in the WWTP. 
The difference between the pollution costs for wastewater and the pollution costs for treated water represents the realized savings in the cost of pollution, i.e., environmental benefits. For example, the suspended particles. The final results of the conducted economic cost-benefit analysis unequivocally indicate the full socio-economic justification for the investment. At the same time, the sensitivity analysis proved that the project is resistant to possible changes in input parameters over time.

Technology Overview
The award winning treatment shaft technology is proposed for the Medical City & Al Zuyut Vertical Waste Treatment Plant. It represents a significant advancement in wastewater treatment methodologies. 
WET has two technologies for wastewater treatment that provide two levels of treatment, these are:

Treatment Shaft (TS) technology for primary treatment that provide skimming, settling, screening and disinfection for most of the pollutant for safe discharge to surface water (Figure 1).
Dual Treatment Shaft (DTS) technology for providing (in addition to primary treatment) secondary and treasury treatment for municipal wastewater and for effluent water reuse for restricted irrigation (Figure 2).











	Figure 1 – Treatment Shaft		    Figure 2 - Double Treatment Shaft	

It’s an innovative and patented design featuring a vertical Treatment Shaft achieves wastewater treatment objectives at a substantially less area for construction, lower cost than traditional alternatives, while controlling odor and simplifying operations.   The Treatment Shaft technology has been proven to treat wastewater discharges and eliminate pollution impact on water resources.  

This award winning technology involves a comprehensive process that includes pre-treatment, primary and secondary treatment phases, and a final disinfection stage. Each phase is designed to efficiently reduce specific pollutants. Modeling the improvements in water markers for the Medical City site we are confident we can meet, and exceed the WHO and Iraqi legal standards for water discharge quality. See the attached calculation sheet for the full model and calculations of the influent, effluent water markers, flow rates, and sludge production, and water quality estimates.
